clusters.title: In Colombia, two separate guerilla attacks kill 18
clusters.neutral_headline: Colombia sees deadly attacks, car bomb, and helicopter downing

items.title: In Colombia, two separate guerilla attacks kill 18
items.standfirst: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and injured dozens in Colombia on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, killing six and wounding more than 60, while a drone brought down a police helicopter at a coca farm in the north. The violence deepens Colombia’s worst security crisis in decades and threatens fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections. FRANCE 24'- Juan Pablo Lucumi has more from our offices in Bogota.
items.content: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and injured dozens in Colombia on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, killing six and wounding more than 60, while a drone brought down a police helicopter at a coca farm in the north. The violence deepens Colombia’s worst security crisis in decades and threatens fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections. FRANCE 24'- Juan Pablo Lucumi has more from our offices in Bogota.

items.title: At least 18 killed and dozens injured in separate Colombia attacks
items.standfirst: A car bomb killed six people in Cali while a downed police helicopter left 12 officers dead.
items.content: A car bomb killed six people in Cali while a downed police helicopter left 12 officers dead.

items.title: Colombia truck bomb, drone attacks kill 18 amid deepening security crisis
items.standfirst: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and wounded dozens in Colombia on Thursday, authorities said, as a truck bomb struck Cali and a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, deepening the country’s worst security crisis in decades.
items.content: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and wounded dozens in Colombia on Thursday, authorities said, as a truck bomb struck Cali and a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, deepening the country’s worst security crisis in decades.

items.title: At least 18 killed in Colombia in drone attack on helicopter, car bombing
items.standfirst: Colombian President Gustavo Petro says armed dissidents, drug trafficking cartels should be considered 'terrorists'.
items.content: Colombian President Gustavo Petro says armed dissidents, drug trafficking cartels should be considered 'terrorists'.

items.title: At least 17 dead after car bombing and helicopter attack
items.standfirst: At least 17 people were killed after a car bombing and an attack on a police helicopter in Colombia, officials have said.
items.content: At least 17 people were killed after a car bombing and an attack on a police helicopter in Colombia, officials have said.

ai_summary: Attacks in Colombia killed at least 18 people and injured dozens, authorities reported.
A car bomb in Cali killed six people and wounded over 60, according to reports.
A drone attack downed a police helicopter at a coca farm in northern Colombia.
The violence is deepening Colombia's security crisis ahead of next year's elections.
President Petro called for armed dissidents and cartels to be considered terrorists.

items.title: OnlyFans owner paid $701m in dividends as platform readies for potential sale
items.standfirst: Streaming platform known for subscription-based adult content reports $1.4bn revenue and rising usageThe owner of OnlyFans was paid $701m (£523m) in dividends last year as the streaming platform best known for offering adult content readies for a potential multibillion-dollar sale.The UK-based company, which offers a range of subscription-based content from sex workers and celebrities, reported revenue of $1.4bn in its 2024 financial year, up 9% compared with the year before, accounts filed at Companies House on Friday show. clusters.title: Erik Menendez's parole denied three decades after parents' murder
clusters.neutral_headline: Erik Menendez denied parole after decades in prison

items.title: Erik Menendez's parole denied three decades after parents' murder
items.standfirst: Erik Menendez was denied parole on Thursday, the California Board of Parole Hearings said, three decades after being jailed for life – along with his brother Lyle – for killing their parents in their Beverly Hills home in 1989. The pair say they acted in self-defense after years of emotional and sexual abuse at the hands of a tyrannical father.
items.content: Erik Menendez was denied parole on Thursday, the California Board of Parole Hearings said, three decades after being jailed for life – along with his brother Lyle – for killing their parents in their Beverly Hills home in 1989. The pair say they acted in self-defense after years of emotional and sexual abuse at the hands of a tyrannical father.

items.title: Erik Menendez denied parole after decades in prison
items.standfirst: California officials have denied Erik Menendez parole after he spent decades in prison for killing his parents in 1989.
items.content: California officials have denied Erik Menendez parole after he spent decades in prison for killing his parents in 1989.

items.title: California parole board denies release of Erik Menendez
items.standfirst: Panel declines to grant parole to Menendez, convicted over parents’ deaths, while brother Lyle faces hearing on FridayThe California board of parole hearings denied the release of Erik Menendez, on Thursday who has spent nearly 30 years in prison since he was convicted with his brother in the shooting deaths of their parents.Erik and Lyle Menendez were sentenced in 1996 to life in prison for fatally shooting their father, Jose Menendez, and mother, Kitty Menendez, in their Beverly Hills mansion in 1989. They were 18 and 21 at the time. While defense attorneys argued the brothers acted out of self-defense after years of sexual abuse by their father, prosecutors said the brothers killed their parents for a multimillion-dollar inheritance. Continue reading...
items.content: Panel declines to grant parole to Menendez, convicted over parents’ deaths, while brother Lyle faces hearing on FridayThe California board of parole hearings denied the release of Erik Menendez, on Thursday who has spent nearly 30 years in prison since he was convicted with his brother in the shooting deaths of their parents.Erik and Lyle Menendez were sentenced in 1996 to life in prison for fatally shooting their father, Jose Menendez, and mother, Kitty Menendez, in their Beverly Hills mansion in 1989. They were 18 and 21 at the time. While defense attorneys argued the brothers acted out of self-defense after years of sexual abuse by their father, prosecutors said the brothers killed their parents for a multimillion-dollar inheritance. Continue reading...

items.title: Thailand former PM cleared of royal insult charge but Shinawatra dynasty’s fate still hangs in balance
items.standfirst: Lese-majesty case against Thaksin Shinawatra is dismissed, but his daughter Paetongtarn will hear next week if she will be removed as prime minsterA criminal court in Thailand has dismissed a case accusing former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra of defaming the monarchy, the first of three court cases that could decide the fate of one of the country’s prominent political families.Thaksin was accused of insulting the monarchy during an interview with South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo in 2015. Continue reading...
items.content: Lese-majesty case against Thaksin Shinawatra is dismissed, but his daughter Paetongtarn will hear next week if she will be removed as prime minsterA criminal court in Thailand has dismissed a case accusing former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra of defaming the monarchy, the first of three court cases that could decide the fate of one of the country’s prominent political families.Thaksin was accused of insulting the monarchy during an interview with South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo in 2015. Continue reading...

items.title: Thai court clears ex-PM Thaksin of royal defamation charges
items.standfirst: A Thai court on Friday cleared former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of royal defamation charges, saying there was not enough evidence to prove wrongdoing. The case stemmed from decades-old remarks Thaksin made in South Korean media that prosecutors said violated Thailand's strict laws prohibiting insults against its royal family.
items.content: A Thai court on Friday cleared former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of royal defamation charges, saying there was not enough evidence to prove wrongdoing. The case stemmed from decades-old remarks Thaksin made in South Korean media that prosecutors said violated Thailand's strict laws prohibiting insults against its royal family.

items.title: Court clears Thailand’s ex-PM Thaksin Shinawatra in royal insult case

items.content: Retired politician and billionaire businessman was accused of violating Thailand's strict laws on insults to royalty.

ai_summary: A Thai court dismissed royal defamation charges against Thaksin Shinawatra.
The charges stemmed from comments made in a South Korean newspaper in 2015.
The court found insufficient evidence to prove wrongdoing by Thaksin.
The case was one of several that could impact the Shinawatra family's future.
Thaksin was accused of violating laws against insulting the royal family.

clusters.title: Newsom signs bill putting new California congressional maps on November ballot
clusters.neutral_headline: Newsom signs bill for new California congressional maps

items.title: Newsom signs bill putting new California congressional maps on November ballot
items.standfirst: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has signed a bill that will allow voters to decide on new congressional maps in November. CBS News reporter Erica Brown has more.
items.content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has signed a bill that will allow voters to decide on new congressional maps in November. CBS News reporter Erica Brown has more.

items.title: Newsom approves California November vote to counter Texas Republican redistricting
items.standfirst: California voters will decide in November on a Democrat-proposed congressional map aiming to secure five more US House seats. This follows Texas Republicans advancing a map for similar GOP gains. Governor Gavin Newsom signed the legislation, escalating a national partisan gerrymandering battle ahead of the midterms.
items.content: California voters will decide in November on a Democrat-proposed congressional map aiming to secure five more US House seats. This follows Texas Republicans advancing a map for similar GOP gains. Governor Gavin Newsom signed the legislation, escalating a national partisan gerrymandering battle ahead of the midterms.

items.title: Newsom signs redistricting proposal to reshape congressional map in favor of Democrats
items.standfirst: Retaliatory strike against gerrymandered maps in Texas now heads to voters in a special election this NovemberCalifornia governor Gavin Newsom on Thursday signed a sweeping redistricting proposal aimed at redrawing the state’s congressional boundaries to create five new Democratic US House seats – a direct response to the gerrymandered maps Republicans in Texas are advancing at the behest of Donald Trump.The Democratic-controlled state legislature voted to advance a legislative package revising California’s maps after hours of debate. With Newsom’s signature, the measure now heads to voters in a special election this November. Continue reading...
items.content: Retaliatory strike against gerrymandered maps in Texas now heads to voters in a special election this NovemberCalifornia governor Gavin Newsom on Thursday signed a sweeping redistricting proposal aimed at redrawing the state’s congressional boundaries to create five new Democratic US House seats – a direct response to the gerrymandered maps Republicans in Texas are advancing at the behest of Donald Trump.The Democratic-controlled state legislature voted to advance a legislative package revising California’s maps after hours of debate. With Newsom’s signature, the measure now heads to voters in a special election this November. Continue reading...

items.title: US lawmakers approve Democrat redistricting plan in California
items.standfirst: Democrats aim to counter Texas GOP bill flipping five Democratic seats to Republican control in US Congress.
items.content: Democrats aim to counter Texas GOP bill flipping five Democratic seats to Republican control in US Congress.

ai_summary: California Governor Newsom signed a bill for a November vote on new maps.
The proposed maps aim to create five new Democratic US House seats.
The bill is a response to Republican redistricting efforts in Texas.
The redistricting proposal will be decided by voters in a special election.
The state legislature voted to advance the redistricting package.

items.title: OpenAI HR Chief Julia Villagra to Exit the Company
items.standfirst: OpenAI Chief People Officer Julia Villagra is leaving the artificial intelligence company effective Friday, vacating a key role at a time when the AI industry is scrambling to attract talent.
items.content: OpenAI Chief People Officer Julia Villagra is leaving the artificial intelligence company effective Friday, vacating a key role at a time when the AI industry is scrambling to attract talent.

The AI industry is trying to attract talent.

items.standfirst: Abu Dhabi’s Space42 is in talks to raise funds to help the satellite communications company expand in Africa and challenge Elon Musk’s Starlink service, which is already operating in eighteen countries on the continent.
items.content: Abu Dhabi’s Space42 is in talks to raise funds to help the satellite communications company expand in Africa and challenge Elon Musk’s Starlink service, which is already operating in eighteen countries on the continent.

clusters.title: Netanyahu says Israel will begin ceasefire talks with Hamas
clusters.neutral_headline: Netanyahu Announces Ceasefire Talks, Gaza City Offensive

items.title: Netanyahu says Israel will begin ceasefire talks with Hamas
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he is willing to restart ceasefire talks with Hamas in exchange for the remaining hostages being released. This comes as Israel launched a ground offensive to take control of Gaza City, calling up 60,000 additional reservists. Protests erupted over news of the most recent offensive, with many hostage families saying this only endangered those still left in Gaza.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he is willing to restart ceasefire talks with Hamas in exchange for the remaining hostages being released. This comes as Israel launched a ground offensive to take control of Gaza City, calling up 60,000 additional reservists. Protests erupted over news of the most recent offensive, with many hostage families saying this only endangered those still left in Gaza.

items.title: Netanyahu announces return to Gaza ceasefire negotiations
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said renewed ceasefire negotiations would go “hand in hand” with the planned expansion of military operations to take full control of Gaza City.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said renewed ceasefire negotiations would go “hand in hand” with the planned expansion of military operations to take full control of Gaza City.

items.title: Netanyahu orders new talks to release all hostages, pushes ahead with Gaza City takeover
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday said he had ordered the beginning of immediate negotiations to release the remaining Israeli hostages in Gaza, rejecting a ceasefire proposal presented earlier this week. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday said he had ordered the beginning of immediate negotiations to release the remaining Israeli hostages in Gaza, rejecting a ceasefire proposal presented earlier this week. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

ai_summary: Netanyahu said Israel will restart ceasefire talks with Hamas.
Talks are contingent on the release of remaining hostages.
Israel is planning to expand military operations to take Gaza City.
Protests erupted over the planned offensive.
Hostage families expressed concerns about the offensive's impact.

clusters.title: Trump administration reviews 55 million visa holders for violations
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump administration reviews 55 million visa holders for violations

items.title: Trump administration reviews 55 million visa holders for violations
items.standfirst: The administration of US President Donald Trump said Thursday it is reviewing more than 55 million valid US visa holders for potential violations that could lead to deportation, in a broadening crackdown on foreigners legally in the country amid heightened immigration enforcement efforts.
items.content: The administration of US President Donald Trump said Thursday it is reviewing more than 55 million valid US visa holders for potential violations that could lead to deportation, in a broadening crackdown on foreigners legally in the country amid heightened immigration enforcement efforts.

items.title: Trump administration says it’s reviewing all 55 million US visa holders
items.standfirst: US State Department said it was continuously vetting all visa holders for possible violations.
items.content: US State Department said it was continuously vetting all visa holders for possible violations.

ai_summary: The Trump administration is reviewing over 55 million US visa holders.
The review aims to identify potential violations.
Violations could lead to deportation.
This is part of increased immigration enforcement efforts.

clusters.title: Ukrainian national arrested over 2022 Nord Stream pipeline blasts
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukrainian national arrested over 2022 Nord Stream pipeline blasts

items.title: Ukrainian national arrested over 2022 Nord Stream pipeline blasts
items.standfirst: Italian authorities have arrested a Ukrainian national suspected of coordinating and taking part in the 2022 sabotage of Nord Stream gas pipelines. The suspect, identified only as Serhii K., was arrested overnight in Italy’s Rimini province, at the request of German federal prosecutors. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.
items.content: Italian authorities have arrested a Ukrainian national suspected of coordinating and taking part in the 2022 sabotage of Nord Stream gas pipelines. The suspect, identified only as Serhii K., was arrested overnight in Italy’s Rimini province, at the request of German federal prosecutors. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.

items.title: Ukrainian man arrested over Nord Stream blasts in 2022
items.standfirst: A Ukrainian suspect has been arrested in Italy over the sabotage of the Nord Stream underwater gas pipelines from Russia to Europe in 2022, German prosecutors said Thursday. Jörg Taszman, journalist in Berlin, has more details.
items.content: A Ukrainian suspect has been arrested in Italy over the sabotage of the Nord Stream underwater gas pipelines from Russia to Europe in 2022, German prosecutors said Thursday. Jörg Taszman, journalist in Berlin, has more details.

items.title: Ukrainian arrested in Italy over Nord Stream attacks, German prosecutors say
items.standfirst: Italian police have arrested a Ukrainian man suspected of coordinating attacks on the Nord Stream pipelines, Germany's prosecutor general said on Thursday.
items.content: Italian police have arrested a Ukrainian man suspected of coordinating attacks on the Nord Stream pipelines, Germany's prosecutor general said on Thursday.

ai_summary: Italian authorities arrested a Ukrainian national.
The suspect is linked to the 2022 Nord Stream pipeline sabotage.
The arrest occurred in Italy's Rimini province.
The arrest was based on a request from German prosecutors.

items.title: Israeli forces enter outskirts of Gaza City, warn Palestinians to leave as offensive begins
items.standfirst: TEL AVIV — Israel entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City on Wednesday after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.
items.content: TEL AVIV — Israel entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City on Wednesday after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.

ai_summary: Israel has begun the first stages of a ground offensive in Gaza City.
Palestinians are fleeing districts in Gaza City.
Israel has called up 60,000 reservists for the operation.

clusters.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan
clusters.neutral_headline: Bus Crash in Afghanistan Kills Over 70 People

items.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Bus crash kills more than 70 Afghans deported from Iran, including 17 children
items.standfirst: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.
items.content: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.

ai_summary: A bus carrying deported Afghans crashed in western Afghanistan.
The crash involved a bus, a motorcycle, and a fuel truck.
At least 78 people died in the collision.
Seventeen children were among the fatalities.
The bus caught fire after the collision.
